name: How to create a public CA signed certificate.txt - Introduction
description: This section introduces the process of creating a private key using the OpenSSL command-line tool. A private key is a crucial component in the process of obtaining a public CA (Certificate Authority) signed certificate, which is commonly used for secure communication over the internet. The section provides a command snippet that can be used to generate a private key file, which is a necessary first step before creating a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) and obtaining a CA-signed certificate.
use_cases: Obtaining a public CA-signed certificate for secure communication (e.g., HTTPS)
Enabling secure data transfer and encryption for web servers, email servers, or other internet-facing services
Establishing trust and identity verification for websites or online services
Implementing secure communication channels for internal applications or services within an organization

name: How to create a public CA signed certificate.txt - 1. To create a private key using openssl
description: This section explains how to create a private key using the OpenSSL command-line tool. It provides a command that generates a new private key and a self-signed certificate, which can be used for testing purposes. However, the self-signed certificate is not suitable for production use, as it is not trusted by web browsers or other clients. The section also includes an example of the prompts and responses required to generate the private key and self-signed certificate.
use_cases: Creating a private key for testing or development purposes
Generating a self-signed certificate for local or internal use
Understanding the process of creating a private key and certificate using OpenSSL
capabilities: Specifying key parameters (algorithm, key size, expiration)
Providing certificate details (organization, common name, email)

name: How to create a public CA signed certificate.txt - 2. Now to generate CSR,
description: This section explains how to generate a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) using the OpenSSL command-line tool. A CSR is a data file that contains information about the organization and the server for which a digital certificate is being requested. The generated CSR file can then be submitted to a Certificate Authority (CA) to obtain a signed SSL/TLS certificate.
use_cases: Obtaining a public CA-signed SSL/TLS certificate for a website or server
Enabling secure communication between client and server applications
Establishing trust and identity verification for online services

name: How to create a public CA signed certificate.txt - 3. Now that you have Certificate Signing Request "domain.csr" you need to create a ticket with #techit to get CSR signed by 3rd party Public CA.
description: This section explains the process of generating a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) for a domain, which is a necessary step to obtain a publicly trusted SSL/TLS certificate from a third-party Certificate Authority (CA). It provides an example of the prompts and information required, such as the fully qualified domain name and an email address. The section also mentions the option to encrypt the CSR file with a password or leave it unencrypted.
use_cases: Obtaining a publicly trusted SSL/TLS certificate for a website or web application
Enabling secure communication (HTTPS) for a domain
Establishing trust and encryption for data transmission over the internet
Complying with security standards and regulations for handling sensitive information

name: How to create a public CA signed certificate.txt - 4. Once you have certificate bundle given by IT, look for the following directory
description: This section explains the process of obtaining a public CA signed certificate bundle from the IT team after submitting a Certificate Signing Request (CSR). It provides details about the directory structure and files that will be received, including the public certificate file with a .crt extension, the private key file, the CA bundle file containing the chain of trust certificates, and plain text versions of these files. The section emphasizes the importance of sharing the CA bundle file with clients or developers if they request it.
use_cases: Obtaining a public CA signed certificate for a domain
Sharing the certificate bundle with clients or developers
Identifying the necessary files in the received certificate bundle
capabilities: CA bundle file (chain of trust certificates)
Plain text versions of certificate files
